review.title: Distributed Power Allocation with SINR Constraints Using Trial and Error Learning
review.abstract: In this paper, we address the problem of global transmit power minimization in a self-congiguring network where radio devices are subject to operate at a minimum signal to interference plus noise ratio (SINR) level. We model the network as a parallel Gaussian interference channel and we introduce a fully decentralized algorithm (based on trial and error) able to statistically achieve a congiguration where the performance demands are met. Contrary to existing solutions, our algorithm requires only local information and can learn stable and efficient working points by using only one bit feedback. We model the network under two different game theoretical frameworks: normal form and satisfaction form. We show that the converging points correspond to equilibrium points, namely Nash and satisfaction equilibrium. Similarly, we provide sufficient conditions for the algorithm to converge in both formulations. Moreover, we provide analytical results to estimate the algorithm's performance, as a function of the network parameters. Finally, numerical results are provided to validate our theoretical conclusions. Keywords: Learning, power control, trial and error, Nash equilibrium, spectrum sharing.

sections.heading: VI. SIMULATION RESULTS
sections.text: The purpose of this section is threefold. Firstly, we run simulations to numerically validate the DTMCs introduced in Sec. V. Secondly, we validate the results on more general channel models, then we evaluate the performance of the algorithm in terms of satisfaction and performance used. The first two experiments were performed for two different parameters. The first set consists of: K = 3, C = 4, = 0.02 and 6 ≤ Q ≤ 10. The second set consists of K = 4, C = 5, = 0.02 and 6 ≤ Q ≤ 10. In our first experiment, we perform 107 iterations to estimate those in two different channel models: the simple channels expressed in (14) and a Rayleigh channel. The results are summarized in Figure 3, as we can see, the analysis applied to specific channel models proves to be sufficiently accurate.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this thesis, we investigated a problem of power control in a self-configuring decentralized network. We presented a new decentralized algorithm that is capable of steering the network to an operating point where the maximum number of pairs of transmitters achieves a sufficient SINR while minimizing the power consumption of the network. The algorithm does not require prior knowledge of the network and can learn an efficient balance with only one bit of feedback. Assuming a certain channel realization, we analytically estimated the expected performance of the algorithm through a Markov chain description of algorithm behavior. Finally, we have shown through Monte Carlo simulations that the analysis is approximately correct even for general channel models.
